If $$\begin{array}{@{}l@{\;}l@{}l@{}l} && & P_b \\ & \times & & P_b \\ \cline{2-4} & & 3 & 1_b, \\ \end{array} $$where $P$ and $b$ represent two distinct digits 0-9 and $P$ is one less than $b$, what is the value of the base $b$?
inference:
The multiplication is in base $b$.
$P_b \times P_b = 31_b$.
In base $b$, $P_b = P \times b^0 = P$ and $31_b = 3 \times b^1 + 1 \times b^0 = 3b + 1$.
So we have $P^2 = 3b + 1$.
Since $P = b-1$, we substitute this into the equation:
$(b-1)^2 = 3b + 1$.
$b^2 - 2b + 1 = 3b + 1$.
$b^2 - 5b = 0$.
$b(b-5) = 0$.
Since $b$ is the base, $b$ must be greater than 3 (since $3b + 1 > 3 \times 3 + 1 = 10$ and we have $31_b$).
$b=5$ or $b=0$.
Since $b$ must be greater than 3, $b = 5$.
Checking $P=5-1=4$.
$4_5 \times 4_5 = 4^2 = 16_{10} = 31_5$ since $16 = 3 \times 5 + 1$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{5}$
ground_truth:
We can rewrite $31_b$ as $3b+1$ in base 10. So, we have $P\cdot P=3b+1$. The value of $P$ is one less than $b$, so we substitute $(b-1)$ for $P$ and get \begin{align*}
(b-1)^2&=3b+1\quad\Rightarrow\\
b^2-2b+1&=3b+1\quad\Rightarrow\\
b^2-5b&=0\quad\Rightarrow\\
b(b-5)&=0.
\end{align*}That means $b=0$ or $b=5$, but a base of 0 would mean $P=-1$ and the multiplication problem would not be true. So, the base $b$ is $\boxed{5}$.
